awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Decrease of Precipitation Extremes at High Temperature and its Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent decades have seen an increasing trend in extreme precipitation intensity (EPI) over much of the globe including the continental US.  The trend is generally regarded as a consequence of increasing temperature, as for the same relative humidity warmer air holds more precipitable water than colder air. Apart from the trend, EPI shows similar variation during weather-related temperature fluctuations between warm and cold days, as extreme precipitation events on colder days tend to be less intense than their counterparts on warmer days.  But in day-to-day temperature fluctuations the increase of EPI with temperature only holds up to a point, beyond which intensity falls off with further increases in temperature.  It is thus of interest to understand why EPI increases with temperature up to a threshold value and then decreases in day-to-day variability, what determines the temperature at which EPI peaks, and how the EPI-temperature relationship changes as a result of long-term increases in temperature.

The PI hypothesizes that the reduction in EPI at the highest temperatures is a consequence of the effect of temperature on the moisture difference between air in convective clouds and the ambient air surrounding them.  Rising air in convective clouds is generally saturated with water vapor while ambient air surrounding the clouds is not, thus the vigor of clouds is suppressed when drier ambient air is mixed into them.  The suppressing effect of ambient air mixed into clouds increases with temperature if the moisture difference between cloud and ambient air increases with temperature, an increase which is expected under reasonable assumptions including a minimal change in ambient relative humidity.  Work under this award examines the role of this moisture deficit mechanism in suppressing the development of deep convective clouds from shallow clouds, thereby reducing extreme precipitation at high temperatures.  The work also considers the change in the EPI-temperature relationship that occurs as climate warms, with the hypothesis that the relationship remains qualitatively the same but the threshold value shifts to progressively higher temperatures.  Additional work considers the possible implications of the moisture deficit mechanism for drought.  The work is carried out through a combination of observational analysis and climate model simulations.

The project has broader impacts due to the severe consequences of extreme precipitation for human activities and the need to understand how the threats posed by extreme precipitation will evolve in a changing climate.  The PI is also engaged in a variety of outreach activities at local schools, including a 5-day workshop for middle- and high-school math and science teachers.  In addition, the project supports a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher, thereby providing for the development of the workforce in this research area.

por.por_cntn:
Temperature is an important factor influencing the variability and changes of the Earth?s hydrological cycle. At the climate timescale (decades or longer), warming causes increased flood and drought risks by increasing extreme precipitation intensity and evapotranspiration; at the weather-to-seasonal timescales, precipitation intensity tends to be lower under high temperature (a phenomenon commonly referred to as ?negative scaling?), and extreme heat tends to co-occur with drought. Combining observational data, reanalysis products, output from CMIP5 and CMIP6 earth system models, and numerical experiments using regional and global climate models, this project enabled us to advance our understanding of the temperature-extreme precipitation relationships at both the weather and climate timescales, and to better understand the role of temperature in drought development and predictability at the sub-seasonal to seasonal timescales.

Based on our analysis of observational and reanalysis data and CMIP model output, the negative scaling of extreme precipitation intensity with temperature at the weather timescale is a general feature observed in all types of climate, and is well captured by earth system models; as climate warms, the general shape of the extreme precipitation-temperature relationship remains similar, but both the peak of extreme precipitation intensity and the temperature at which it peaks increase and their increases conform to the Clausius-Clapeyron (C-C)  relationship. The negative scaling over ocean is primarily a reflection of precipitation-induced cooling; over land, precipitation cooling plays a minor role. The primary cause for the negative scaling over land is the large saturation deficit caused by high temperature in hot weather, which suppresses deep convection and limits the cumulus updraft condensation rate during the storms.

To further elucidate the role of atmospheric saturation deficit, we eliminate the impact of saturation deficit through an analysis focused exclusively on saturated atmosphere. The results revealed that the extreme precipitation intensity increases monotonically with temperature when there is no saturation deficit, showing no negative scaling in observations or in earth system models. Moreover, observational data indicates that the positive scaling ratio of precipitation intensity with pre-storm local temperature closely follows the C-C relationship. In addition to increasing precipitation intensity through thermodynamics as reflected by C-C relationship, temperature also influences precipitation concentration. Our event-scale analysis showed that precipitation events under higher temperatures tend to be more concentrated both spatially and temporally, which further enhances flooding risks.

At the sub-seasonal to seasonal timescales, drought and extreme heat tend to co-occur, with significant consequences for ecosystems. Plant photosynthesis responds to both soil water stress and atmospheric aridity, both of which intensify with the development of drought and heat events. Our observation-based analysis showed that plant responses at the early stage of drought development lead to a strong signal of sub-seasonal trajectory of photosynthesis (as captured by satellite remote sensing of solar induced fluorescence), a faster-than-usual decrease or a slower-than-usual increase.  This trajectory anomalies can serve as an early warning signal for flash drought onset with a lead time of weeks to months. In addition, using a newly proposed method for land surface initialization, numerical experiments with the Community Earth System Model enabled us to assess the contribution of soil moisture and soil temperature feedback at the sub-seasonal timescales, and showed that initial soil moisture plays a much more important role than initial temperature in the development of compound heat-drought events.

Research findings from this project have been disseminated through journal articles (six published, one in press, one submitted, and one in preparation) and a large number of presentations at scientific conferences (AGU, AMS, and CESM meetings). The project contributed to the STEM workforce through supporting the training of one postdoctoral scholar (who is now a staff scientist at the DOE Los Alamos National Lab) and one PhD student (who is now a postdoctoral researcher in Columbia University). In addition, the project enabled the PI and her team to engage in outreach activities with presentations to the general public and environmental stakeholders at multiple municipality levels. Data and model output from the project were also used for the teaching of undergraduate and graduate students at UConn.
